articles.headline: Fill Up on Corn if You Can
articles.snippet: Even in the Midwest where ethanol is most popular, its success as an alternative fuel is far from assured.
articles.abstract: Even in the Midwest where ethanol is most popular, its success as an alternative fuel is far from assured.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Ill. — Standing next to his pickup truck at a service station here, Robert Beck squeezed a yellow nozzle and filled up with the corn-based fuel blend of 85 percent ethanol and 15 percent gasoline that car companies, farmers and politicians alike love to promote as a way out of America’s oil addiction.

articles.headline: Bulky Boxes That Can Take Great Photos
articles.snippet: Three new models of digital S.L.R. cameras demonstrate just how fast single-lens reflex technology is advancing.
articles.abstract: Three new models of digital S.L.R. cameras demonstrate just how fast single-lens reflex technology is advancing.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU may be perfectly satisfied with the snapshots taken by your sleek, slim, silver shirt-pocket digital camera. But then you see pictures in magazines that you just know were taken with better equipment. You know: razor-sharp portraits with blurred backgrounds. Car taillights drawing bright orange tracks across the nighttime frame. A waterfall, smoothed by a slow shutter into a silky veil. Or just about anything that happens fast.

articles.headline: An Apple-Google Friendship, and a Common Enemy
articles.snippet: The alliance between Google and Apple may make the prospect of outdueling Microsoft’s empire better than ever.
articles.abstract: The alliance between Google and Apple may make the prospect of outdueling Microsoft’s empire better than ever.

articles.headline: Shaky Darfur Peace at Risk as New Fighting Looms
articles.snippet: The Sudanese government is preparing a fresh assault on the rebel groups that refused to sign a peace agreement.
articles.abstract: The Sudanese government is preparing a fresh assault on the rebel groups that refused to sign a peace agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL FASHER, Sudan, Aug. 30 — At the airstrip here in the heart of Darfur, the Ilyushin cargo planes fly in day after day, their holds packed with the stuff of war: troops, trucks, bombs and guns.

articles.headline: U.S. Drafting Sanctions as Iran Ignores Deadline
articles.snippet: Sanctions the U.S. is seeking could start with restrictions on Iran’s imports of nuclear material, but the plan faces a high hurdle at the U.N.
articles.abstract: Sanctions the U.S. is seeking could start with restrictions on Iran’s imports of nuclear material, but the plan faces a high hurdle at the U.N.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 — With Iran defying a Thursday deadline to halt production of nuclear fuel, the United States and three European allies are assembling a list of sanctions they would seek in the United Nations Security Council, beginning with restrictions on imports of nuclear-related equipment and material.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Storm Passes, but Insurance Worries Stay
articles.snippet: Nowhere are insurance rates more severe than in Florida, where storms in recent years have added billions to the insurers’ losses.
articles.abstract: Nowhere are insurance rates more severe than in Florida, where storms in recent years have added billions to the insurers’ losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI, Aug. 30 — Jim Pozo felt he got a break on Wednesday when Tropical Storm Ernesto turned out to be nothing more than a slightly windy rainstorm as it crossed South Florida.

articles.headline: Revision Lifts Pace of Growth
articles.snippet: The economy grew more quickly in the second quarter than initially estimated and inflation was slightly lower.
articles.abstract: The economy grew more quickly in the second quarter than initially estimated and inflation was slightly lower.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy grew more quickly in the second quarter than initially estimated and inflation was slightly lower, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

articles.headline: Shaky Darfur Peace at Risk as New Fighting Looms
articles.snippet: At the airstrip here in the heart of Darfur, the Ilyushin cargo planes fly in day after day, their holds packed with the stuff of war: troops, trucks, bombs and guns.      So far, negotiations over a proposed United Nations force to shore up the s...
articles.abstract: At the airstrip here in the heart of Darfur, the Ilyushin cargo planes fly in day after day, their holds packed with the stuff of war: troops, trucks, bombs and guns.      So far, negotiations over a proposed United Nations force to shore up the shaky peace in Darfur have limped along with no sign of compromise. The opposing sides in the conflict now seem headed toward a large-scale military confrontation, bringing Darfur to the edge of a new abyss -- perhaps the deepest it has faced.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL FASHER, Sudan, Aug. 30 - At the airstrip here in the heart of Darfur, the Ilyushin cargo planes fly in day after day, their holds packed with the stuff of war: troops, trucks, bombs and guns.

articles.headline: Fill Up on Corn if You Can
articles.snippet: Standing next to his pickup truck at a service station here, Robert Beck squeezed a yellow nozzle and filled up with the corn-based fuel blend of 85 percent ethanol and 15 percent gasoline that car companies, farmers and politicians alike love to ...
articles.abstract: Standing next to his pickup truck at a service station here, Robert Beck squeezed a yellow nozzle and filled up with the corn-based fuel blend of 85 percent ethanol and 15 percent gasoline that car companies, farmers and politicians alike love to promote as a way out of America's oil addiction.     Mr. Beck, a bearded agronomist who travels throughout the Midwest, likes the idea of E-85, as the fuel blend is known, because it is made mostly from a domestic crop. But he still finds that buying the fuel is almost more trouble than it is worth.

articles.headline: Students’ Paths to Small Colleges Can Bypass SAT
articles.snippet: It is still far too early to sound the death knell, but for many small liberal arts colleges, the SAT may have outlived its usefulness.     Since Bowdoin and Bates dropped their testing requirements decades ago, more than a fourth of U.S. News & W...
articles.abstract: It is still far too early to sound the death knell, but for many small liberal arts colleges, the SAT may have outlived its usefulness.     Since Bowdoin and Bates dropped their testing requirements decades ago, more than a fourth of U.S. News & World Report's Top 100 liberal arts colleges have made admissions exams optional, and new ones are joining the list at a quickening pace.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is still far too early to sound the death knell, but for many small liberal arts colleges, the SAT may have outlived its usefulness.

articles.headline: Officials Reach California Deal to Cut Emissions
articles.snippet: California's political leaders announced an agreement on Wednesday that imposes the most sweeping controls on carbon dioxide emissions in the nation, putting the state at the forefront of a broad campaign to curb the man-made causes of climate cha...
articles.abstract: California's political leaders announced an agreement on Wednesday that imposes the most sweeping controls on carbon dioxide emissions in the nation, putting the state at the forefront of a broad campaign to curb the man-made causes of climate change despite resistance in Washington.     The deal between the Democratic-controlled Legislature and the Republican governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger, calls for a 25 percent reduction in carbon dioxide emissions by 2020, and could establish controls on the largest industrial sectors, including utilities, oil refineries and cement plants. The state has already placed strict limits on automobile emissions, although that move is being challenged in federal court.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO, Aug. 30 - California's political leaders announced an agreement on Wednesday that imposes the most sweeping controls on carbon dioxide emissions in the nation, putting the state at the forefront of a broad campaign to curb the man-made causes of climate change despite resistance in Washington.

articles.headline: U.S. Drafting Sanctions as Iran Ignores Deadline
articles.snippet: With Iran defying a Thursday deadline to halt production of nuclear fuel, the United States and three European allies are assembling a list of sanctions they would seek in the United Nations Security Council, beginning with restrictions on imports...
articles.abstract: With Iran defying a Thursday deadline to halt production of nuclear fuel, the United States and three European allies are assembling a list of sanctions they would seek in the United Nations Security Council, beginning with restrictions on imports of nuclear-related equipment and material.      Eventually, punitive measures might expand to restrict travel by Iran's leaders and limit the country's access to global financial markets, according to diplomatic officials involved in the talks who spoke only on condition of anonymity.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 - With Iran defying a Thursday deadline to halt production of nuclear fuel, the United States and three European allies are assembling a list of sanctions they would seek in the United Nations Security Council, beginning with restrictions on imports of nuclear-related equipment and material.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Storm Passes, but Insurance Worries Stay
articles.snippet: Jim Pozo felt he got a break on Wednesday when Tropical Storm Ernesto turned out to be nothing more than a slightly windy rainstorm as it crossed South Florida.     And that was not just because his three-bedroom house near downtown Miami was unsc...
articles.abstract: Jim Pozo felt he got a break on Wednesday when Tropical Storm Ernesto turned out to be nothing more than a slightly windy rainstorm as it crossed South Florida.     And that was not just because his three-bedroom house near downtown Miami was unscathed. He had been worried, he said, that a storm causing even modest damage would push up his already sky-high insurance premiums.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI, Aug. 30 - Jim Pozo felt he got a break on Wednesday when Tropical Storm Ernesto turned out to be nothing more than a slightly windy rainstorm as it crossed South Florida.

articles.headline: Revision Lifts Pace of Growth
articles.snippet: The economy grew more quickly in the second quarter than initially estimated and inflation was slightly lower, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.     While the revisions were largely in line with expectations, economists said the report w...
articles.abstract: The economy grew more quickly in the second quarter than initially estimated and inflation was slightly lower, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.     While the revisions were largely in line with expectations, economists said the report was a welcome sign at a time of significant uncertainty about the economy's direction.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy grew more quickly in the second quarter than initially estimated and inflation was slightly lower, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

articles.headline: An Apple-Google Friendship, and a Common Enemy
articles.snippet: When Eric E. Schmidt, Google's chief executive, was named to Apple Computer's board this week, it did more than signal a potential alliance between powerful companies. It touched off a wave of speculation about the motives of the man behind the mo...
articles.abstract: When Eric E. Schmidt, Google's chief executive, was named to Apple Computer's board this week, it did more than signal a potential alliance between powerful companies. It touched off a wave of speculation about the motives of the man behind the move: Apple's co-founder, Steven P. Jobs.      ''The old social networks in Silicon Valley run very deep,'' noted AnnaLee Saxenian, a leading scholar of the industry and dean of the School of Information at the University of California, Berkeley. ''And this reminds us that Silicon Valley has a common enemy to the north.''

articles.headline: Live Long? Die Young? Answer Isn’t Just in Genes
articles.snippet: Josephine Tesauro never thought she would live so long. At 92, she is straight backed, firm jawed and vibrantly healthy, living alone in an immaculate brick ranch house high on a hill near McKeesport, a Pittsburgh suburb. She works part time in a ...
articles.abstract: Josephine Tesauro never thought she would live so long. At 92, she is straight backed, firm jawed and vibrantly healthy, living alone in an immaculate brick ranch house high on a hill near McKeesport, a Pittsburgh suburb. She works part time in a hospital gift shop and drives her 1995 white Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera to meetings of her four bridge groups, to church and to the grocery store. She has outlived her husband, who died nine years ago, when he was 84. She has outlived her friends, and she has outlived three of her six brothers.     Mrs. Tesauro does, however, have a living sister, an identical twin. But she and her twin are not so identical anymore. Her sister is incontinent, she has had a hip replacement, and she has a degenerative disorder that destroyed most of her vision. She also has dementia. ''She just does not comprehend,'' Mrs. Tesauro says.
articles.lead_paragraph: Josephine Tesauro never thought she would live so long. At 92, she is straight backed, firm jawed and vibrantly healthy, living alone in an immaculate brick ranch house high on a hill near McKeesport, a Pittsburgh suburb. She works part time in a hospital gift shop and drives her 1995 white Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera to meetings of her four bridge groups, to church and to the grocery store. She has outlived her husband, who died nine years ago, when he was 84. She has outlived her friends, and she has outlived three of her six brothers.

articles.headline: Bulky Boxes That Can Take Great Photos
articles.snippet: YOU may be perfectly satisfied with the snapshots taken by your sleek, slim, silver shirt-pocket digital camera. But then you see pictures in magazines that you just know were taken with better equipment. You know: razor-sharp portraits with blurr...
articles.abstract: YOU may be perfectly satisfied with the snapshots taken by your sleek, slim, silver shirt-pocket digital camera. But then you see pictures in magazines that you just know were taken with better equipment. You know: razor-sharp portraits with blurred backgrounds. Car taillights drawing bright orange tracks across the nighttime frame. A waterfall, smoothed by a slow shutter into a silky veil. Or just about anything that happens fast.     Shots like these are child's play, however, for the digital S.L.R. (single-lens reflex) camera. These bulky black bricks don't fit into any pocket except a kangaroo's, and they don't capture digital movies -- but they start up and focus instantaneously and produce spectacular photographs.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU may be perfectly satisfied with the snapshots taken by your sleek, slim, silver shirt-pocket digital camera. But then you see pictures in magazines that you just know were taken with better equipment. You know: razor-sharp portraits with blurred backgrounds. Car taillights drawing bright orange tracks across the nighttime frame. A waterfall, smoothed by a slow shutter into a silky veil. Or just about anything that happens fast.
